Peter is the scion of a wealthy Pittsburgh family. He and his bride-to-be smile and acknowledge the applause and AD-LIBBED toasts. direction.raw_text: I don't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then why are you going?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just doing someone a favor.    How come you're not going?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm persona non grata.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's that mean?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know what it means.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What happened with you and Eleanor?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing. I just outlived my usefulness, that's all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How were you `useful' to her?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Christ, use your imagination. Doug has no reply to that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eleanor was just looking for a way out. A way out of the whole Abbott world. And it turns out that it takes a lot to get away. It's not enough that you sleep around with boys from your world, you have to fuck boys from the wrong side of the tracks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you mean? Like guys from Fountain Park?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, I mean me.     She was fucking me. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 67       CONTINUED:   (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're not from the wrong side of the tracks. Jacey hangs up the nozzle and screws the gas cap back on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wouldn't go to that party if I were you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, you're not me. We're just as good as the Abbotts. Doug hands Jacey a few dollars.   Jacey heads for the office.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You still don't know, do you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Know what? 68       INT. TEXACO STATION (DOWNTOWN HALEY) - OFFICE -             68 CONTINUOUS ACTION Doug follows Jacey inside as he rings up the sale.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Know what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: After Dad died... Mom... had an affair with Lloyd Abbott. That's how he got Dad's patent away from her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't believe you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Believe it or not. I don't care.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're full of shit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then why don't you go ask Mom? Ask her what happened -- ask her why she doesn't have any friends
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Doug walks home from summer school. He pauses to watch the workmen erecting the party tent in the Abbott's front yard.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: ask her why she's never invited to the Abbott's -- ask her which side of the tracks we live on? Jacey shoves the cash register drawer shut. INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 2/16/96                   40. 69     INT. ABBOTT HOME - TENT - NIGHT                              69 The party is well underway, it's a younger crowd tonight. The band plays "Fly Me To The Moon." Doug stands apart from the others. He's ill-at-ease. His conversation with Jacey resonates within him. As he looks over the gathering, he's pained to discover how easy it is to see things the way Jacey does: Lloyd holding court with a group of men in tuxedos... Joan Abbott propelling a reluctant Alice towards a group of guests Alice's age (Alice and Peter have separated)... and, finally, Pamela dancing with a handsome young man (TED). She is the belle of the ball, radiant and suddenly mature in her beautiful gown. She smiles as she sees Doug, excuses herself, and comes over to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How long have you been here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A while.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you okay?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm fine.    Having fun?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, I am.    Come on, dance with me. She pulls him towards the dance floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You didn't tell me I had to dance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just one dance and we'll be even. I won't have to be mad at you anymore and you won't have to be so sorry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What am I supposed to be so sorry about?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, you're not sorry?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right, yeah, I'm sorry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sorry about what? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 69     CONTINUED:                                                    69 DOUG You always do this to me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You said you weren't sorry and now you say you are. So maybe I'm not sure what you're sorry about?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry for what I'm supposed to be sorry about. Okay?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're sorry for feeling me up?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, shit, come on, Pam. Dammit. For crying out loud. Forget it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I accept your apology.   Let's dance. Doug allows Pam to pull him out onto the dance floor. He feels like a dolt, but she arranges his hands on her and they begin to dance. She gazes into his eyes and smiles:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi. Pam is in love with Doug, she has been since they were children. Doug is mellowed by his tender feelings for her. For a golden minute they are in pleasurable bubble of true affinity. But their bubble begins to deflate as Doug sees Joan Abbott staring at them. Her disapproval is unmistakable. Doug steers Pam around the dance floor to avoid Joan's eyes, but then he sees Lloyd Abbott. Lloyd's stare is even more discomforting. Pamela senses the change in Doug's mood, but she is unaware of the cause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is Jacey home for the summer or is he just here for a visit? The mention of his brother's name at this exact moment sends a chill down Doug's spine. (CONTINUED) INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 2/16/96                   42. 69     CONTINUED:    (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Home for the summer. (slight beat) It's cheaper if he stays here for the summer. He can save more money for school, 'cause he doesn't have to pay rent. Money's tight, you know, we're sort of poor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're not poor, are you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hell -- you kidding? Even with Jacey working summers, my mom had to borrow against the house so he could go to Penn. I don't know where the money'll come from for me to go to college. Doug sees Joan Abbott prompting Ted to cut in on his dance with Pamela. Doug's bitterness swells.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hear Alice and Peter are getting a divorce.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're just separated.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's the difference?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know, you'll have to ask them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So, where's Eleanor tonight?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eleanor's... just not here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is she pregnant?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No!    Who said that? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 69     CONTINUED:   (3)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know, everybody in town is saying something different -- she got knocked up, she ran away, your old man kicked her out. So, which is it? Ted steps over and taps Doug on the shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fuck off. Ted is taken aback.   Pamela's eyes fill with tears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why do you hate me so much?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excuse me, asshole, but... Doug spins and slugs Ted in the jaw -- sending him reeling into the other dancers. Everyone pulls away from Doug and Pam. Doug massages his fist and looks helplessly at Pamela:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't hate you. 70     INT. HOLT HOME - DOUG'S BEDROOM - LATER THAT NIGHT            70 The hall light is on but the bedroom is dark. Doug lies on his bed (still dressed). Jacey appears in the doorway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You asleep?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nope. 71     EXT. HOLT HOME - GARAGE - NIGHT (SHORT TIME LATER)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doug and Jacey play another hard fought game of ping-pong in the garage. In the midst of a volley Doug says:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm gonna go to Penn like you. Jacey snorts with incredulous laughter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're gonna what? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 71       CONTINUED:                                                   71 DOUG I'm going to the University of Pennsylvania. I think I'm going to be an architect, too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Like hell you are.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why not? Maybe we can be roommates in Philadelphia?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're nuts. You'll never get accepted to Penn. Besides, Mom couldn't afford it anyway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll get a scholarship.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I had a four-point-0 grade average and I couldn't get a scholarship
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: so, I say you got your head up your ass. Jacey skillfully manipulates the volley and wins the game with a savage return that Doug is unable to counter. Jacey smiles, puts his paddle down, and walks out of the garage. Doug quickly picks up a ping-pong ball and hits it into the back of Jacey's head. Jacey turns and shoots a perturbed look at Doug -- Doug smiles:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'Night. 72       INT. WOMEN'S APPAREL STORE (DOWNTOWN HALEY) - DAY            72 (WINTER, 1958) Helen looks over the merchandise. Doug absent-mindedly trails after his mother as he studies a large brochure about the University of Pennsylvania.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's 'scenic design'?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In what context?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What a minute -- it's theatre.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mmmm? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 72       CONTINUED:                                                    72 DOUG (re: brochure) 'The Howard Lambert Scholarship in Scenic Design for the Theatre.' It's a full ride, four years. Pays everything almost. Hell, I could do that. Just have to figure out what scenic design is. Doug looks up from the brochure and comes face-to-face with a mannequin wearing a bra, girdle, and stockings. He almost flinches with surprise and blushes profusely:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll wait for you outside, Ma. 73       EXT. LADIES APPAREL STORE (DOWNTOWN HALEY) - MOVIE            73 THEATER - SIDEWALK - DAY (MINUTES LATER) It's snowing -- Doug paces to keep warm. He momentarily forgets the cold as he sees Pam and three of her girl friends come out of the drugstore across the street. The girls are in high spirits as they get into Pam's car. Two well-dressed townswomen (MURIEL and DORIS) encounter Helen on their way into the apparel shop as she steps out onto the sidewalk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello, Muriel... Doris. The women pass by Helen with obvious reserve. Helen is seemingly unruffled by their distant responses. She observes Doug as he watches Pam and her friends drive off. Helen and Doug walk up sidewalk (towards the movie theater -- the marquee reads: KIM NOVAK -- JEFF CHANDLER -- JEANNE EAGELS):
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why don't you drop me off at home and take the car and go out with your friends. Go have some fun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why don't you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why don't I what? Go hang out at the Dog'n'Suds? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 73       CONTINUED:                                                     73 DOUG No, go out -- play bridge or whatever adults do for fun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I read for fun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You read too much.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You sound like your brother.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on -- let's go see a movie. 74       INT. MOVIE THEATER (DOWNTOWN HALEY) - DAY                      74 Doug and Helen share a bag of popcorn as they wait for the feature to begin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Came here on my very first date with Charlie. Saw Rosalie with Nelson Eddy and... not Jeanette MacDonald... oh... Eleanor Powell.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did Dad kiss you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. (slight beat) I kissed him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right, Mom. 75       OMITTED                                                        75 76       EXT. HIGH SCHOOL - PLAYING FIELD - GYMNASIUM - DAY             76 (SUMMER, 1959) The commencement exercises are being held in the sweltering gym to accommodate the large crowd of proud parents and family members. Doug, hot and uncomfortable in his cap and gown, is seated among his fellow graduates behind the podium. The PRINCIPAL (at the podium) announces the names of the graduates as he calls them forward to receive their diplomas. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 76     CONTINUED:                                                     76 PRINCIPAL Pamela Louise Abbott... Pamela rises from her seat and takes her diploma. Lloyd and Joan Abbott applaud their daughter. Joan stands to take a snapshot. Alice is occupied with her restless and fussy eighteen-month-old daughter, Susan. Doug watches Pam return to her seat; she avoids his eyes. Helen is all smiles, this is a very special day for her. The chair next to her is empty. She glances behind her and sees Jacey standing in the back of the gym. Jacey idly surveys the gathering with irritable boredom. He is only there at his mother's insistence. His eyes settle on... Alice Abbott. Alice tries to quiet her CRYING eighteen-month-old daughter (SUSAN). Lloyd makes a reprimanding aside to Alice and she rises and carries Susan up the aisle. Jacey's eyes follow Alice -- she notices his stare as she passes by with Susan in her arms. 77     EXT. HIGH SCHOOL - PARKING LOT - LATER THAT DAY                77 Commencement is over -- the parking lot is a sea of cars slowly negotiating through the mob of celebrating graduates, beaming parents, and rambunctious siblings. As Helen slips through the crowd she is pleasantly ambushed by three (second grade) students of hers. She has a brief exchange with the children and then moves on. Helen finds herself face-to-face with Lloyd Abbott as they both attempt to pass through a narrow space between two parked vehicles. They are both caught off-guard -- there is no graceful way for them to squeeze past each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Congratulations, Helen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you. Congratulations to you, too. Where's Pam going to school?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hmm... Christ, I forgot. (MORE) (CONTINUED) INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 2/16/96                    48. 77     CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bryn Mawr. I should be able to remember that. It costs enough.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She'll do well there -- a very bright girl.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And Doug -- he's going to...?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He got a scholarship to the University of Pennsylvania -- scenic design -- theater.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Same school as...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jacey.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Right.   Well.    Congratulations.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, Lloyd. They pass each other and head their separate ways.   Their chance meeting has not gone unobserved: Joan Abbott has been watching them from the front seat of Lloyd's brand-new 1959 Cadillac. She pretends to repair her lipstick with her compact mirror as Lloyd slips behind the wheel. And Helen finds Jacey frowning at her. He opens the door so that she can get into the Plymouth (Doug is already in the back seat). Jacey glares at Lloyd as he walks around the car and gets in behind the wheel. Lloyd flips down his sun visor (to block Jacey's glare) and pulls out of his parking spot. 78     INT. IRON SKILLET RESTAURANT - THAT NIGHT                     78 A waitress walks across the busy diner to Helen, Jacey, and Doug at their table. Helen and Doug are eating their desserts -- Jacey is content to brood over his cup of coffee. The waitress puts their bill on the table and steps away. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 78     CONTINUED:                                                     78 As Helen starts to open her purse Webb Crosby appears and picks up the bill.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's on the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, Webb, really -- that's not necessary.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How many restaurants got an Ivy League busboy? That's worth a free meal. Charlie'd be real proud of these two highbrows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, he would.     He'd be extremely proud.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You take good care of your little brother in Philadelphia, you hear me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir. 79     EXT. ABBOTT HOME - STREET - NIGHT (SHORT TIME LATER)
direction.name: direction

result.heading: KIM NOVAK -- JEFF CHANDLER -- JEANNE EAGELS

direction.raw_text: The Holt family drives home from the restaurant -- Jacey driving, Helen in front, and Doug in the back seat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What a wonderful night. What a wonderful day. My two Ivy League boys. This is torture for Jacey. Doug looks out the window at the striped tent in the Abbott's front yard as they pass by. A party for the "Class of 1959" is underway (as a banner on the tent proclaims). The street is lined with parked cars and busy with late-coming guests. Doug checks the rearview mirror for Jacey's reaction, but his brother keeps his eyes on the road.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I never understood that tent. I wonder if they own it? I'm surprised they don't just leave it up all year long. (MORE) (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 79     CONTINUED:                                                   79 HELEN (CONT'D) (slight beat) Lloyd's mother was a tough old bird. She sold eggs. They had a place way out on Ditch Road near County Line. That was ages ago. Poor Lloyd had to walk all that way in to school and then back everyday. Charlie used to call Lloyd 'Egg-head' and he didn't mean smart. (another beat) I'm in the mood for ice cream. 80     EXT. HOLT HOME - FRONT PORCH - LATER THAT NIGHT              80 Jacey and Doug sit on the porch steps eating bowls of ice cream. Helen rises from the porch swing and takes her empty bowl inside the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think I'll have one more scoop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ping-pong?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Too hot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You want to go out to the lake and get a couple beers?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, I don't want to go out to the... (exhales) Goddammit. Goddammit! Look, I don't want you in Philadelphia. I don't need you around to remind everybody that I come from Hicksville, U.S.A. So if you're going to go to Philadelphia, you're on your own, dip shit. I don't need you riding my coat tails. Christ -- why don't you get your own life? Stop being my fucking shadow. Doug digests Jacey's insult, then scoops a ball of ice cream out of his bowl with his spoon and flings the gooey ice cream into the side of Jacey's face. Doug rises and goes to the front door. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 80     CONTINUED:                                                     80 DOUG Screw you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You little prick! Jacey hurls his BOWL at Doug -- it misses and SHATTERS on the wall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Missed me, peckerhead. As Doug opens the screen door Jacey dives into him -- they fall into the porch swing with such force that its chains rip out of the porch ceiling and Doug, Jacey, and the swing go overboard off the end of the porch into the shrubs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doug?    Jacey? What was that? Doug and Jacey scramble to their feet, their clothes are ripped and disheveled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're dead, dip shit!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You gotta catch me first, asshole! Doug takes off with Jacey in hot pursuit. A few beats later, Helen steps out onto the front porch and discovers her sons and the porch swing missing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jacey?   Doug? 81     EXT. HOLT HOME AND STREET - NIGHT                              81 Jacey races up a driveway -- Doug is nowhere to be seen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, weasel dick! Come on out, you chicken shit! A collection of GARBAGE CANS EXPLODE in all directions as Doug pops up from behind them and bolts down the driveway. Jacey chases after him, following him across the street. They pay no heed to Helen (in the b.g.) standing in their front yard, calling out to them:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Douglas Lee!     John Charles!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 82     NEIGHBORHOOD - HOLT HOME                                      82 Porch lights are turning on up and down the block and the neighborhood DOGS begin to HOWL as Doug leads Jacey between two houses. 83     NEIGHBORHOOD - HOLT HOME                                      83 Doug jumps up onto a tall wooden fence. He gets halfway over when Jacey leaps up and grabs him and the fence collapses, dumping them into a back yard vegetable garden. 84     NEIGHBORHOOD - HOLT HOME                                      84 Doug and Jacey wrestle and grapple in the muddy soil, cursing each other and crushing the rows of green crops. MRS. PORTER appears at her back door brandishing a broom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Git!   Stop that! You two git! She sails into combat with her broom swinging. But Doug and Jacey are unwilling to give up the fight -- they are finally separated by a strong blast of water. They sputter for breath and discover that Helen is holding the hose. 85     EXT. MRS. PORTER'S HOUSE - DAY (NEXT DAY)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That board doesn't look straight, Jacey. Come on, Doug, you've been painting the same spot for the last five minutes. 86     EXT. HOLT HOME - GARAGE - NIGHT                               86 Doug and Jacey clean their hands with turpentine. Doug picks up a ping-pong paddle and bounces the ball on it, trying to see how long he can keep it bouncing. Jacey finishes cleaning up, picks up a paddle, and then, without a word, Doug serves the ball and they begin to volley.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 87     EXT. ROAD (COUNTRYSIDE) - DAY                                  87 The Plymouth drives along the two-lane blacktop past the fields of tall, green corn. Doug is driving, Helen sits beside him. She reacts to something in the distance:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Isn't that Pamela Abbott? In the distance Pamela struggles with a jack as she tries to remove a flat tire on her convertible. Doug grimaces as he recognizes her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is Pam.    Pull over. Doug reluctantly pulls over beside Pam's car. She's no more pleased to see Doug than he is to see her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi, Pam.   Do you need some help?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi, Mrs. Holt. It's so darn hot the stupid jack just keeps sinking into the pavement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, maybe Doug can give you a hand? Doug frowns and slowly climbs out of the Plymouth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where's the thing that goes on the bottom of the jack?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What thing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The thing, the base that the jack fits into? (finds it in her open trunk) This.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, I thought that was just the 'spare-tire-holder-on-er.'
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Read your manual. Pamela would slug him if his mother wasn't present. (CONTINUED) INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 2/16/96                     54. 87     CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doug releases the load on the jack and strains to extract it from the molten pavement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pam, would you mind running Doug home? I'd like to get to the bank before they close.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mom...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure, Mrs. Holt, I'll drive him home. Thanks for stopping.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course.   Bye-bye. Helen slides over behind the wheel and drives away. Doug fumes silently while he reassembles the jack. 88     INT. IRON SKILLET RESTAURANT - DAY                           88 Jacey sits at the counter at the rear of the busy diner sipping an iced tea. He sees Alice Abbott enter -- she pulls a dollar bill out of her purse as she approaches the cash register near the front door. She calls out to a waitress who is fetching an order from the grill.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excuse me -- could I get change for a dollar? The waitress is too distracted to take notice of Alice and Alice herself doesn't notice Jacey as he steps up behind her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can I help you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, I need change for... (turns to him) Oh... you don't work here, do you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. I was just thinking about you. I was going to call you tonight. (CONTINUED) INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 2/16/96                   55. 88     CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?   Why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's a picnic out at River Point on Sunday -- I wanted to invite you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I couldn't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bring Susan, kids love picnics.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I need change for the parking meter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here. Jacey opens his palm and reveals the correct change. Alice nervously exchanges the dollar bill for the coins.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, thanks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you have time for an ice tea?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My mother's waiting by the car so I won't get a ticket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe she'd like an ice tea, too?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No harm asking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.   Don't do that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why not?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know why. (CONTINUED) INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 2/16/96                     56. 88     CONTINUED:    (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then I'll make you a deal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I just came in to get some change.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come to the picnic on Sunday and I'll wait here and let you leave first, so your mother won't see me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't care if my mother sees you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then you won't care if I ask her if she'd like to join us for an ice tea?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No!    Wait. Jacey turns to her.
direction.name: direction

HOLT HOME - DINING ROOM - LATER THAT NIGHT                126 Doug and Helen sit across from each other, neither one has much of an appetite. They eat in silence for a few moments, then:

direction.raw_text: Dammit... why can't he just leave them alone?

direction.raw_text: And he just needs that somehow. Well, actually, I know how. She rises and picks up her plate. 127     INT. HOLT HOME - KITCHEN - CONTINUOUS ACTION - NIGHT          127 Helen carries her plate to the sink.   Doug follows her in.

direction.raw_text: What do you mean, how do you know? She sits at the kitchen table and sighs as if coming around to some central, hard truth.

direction.raw_text: I was just a wreck when Charlie died. (MORE) (CONTINUED) INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 3/20/96                   83. 127   CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jacey was almost two and I was eight months pregnant with you and... well, some mornings I'd be crying before I even woke up. Then you were born. And Jacey just got lost in there. I didn't have anything for him. Mother took him over. He'd cry or call for me, and then I'd hear Mother answer him, and I'd go back to sleep. (sighs bitterly) I should've taken us away from here, gone somewhere else.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: After Charlie died Lloyd Abbott started dropping by on his way home from work. He felt so bad about that bet Charlie made with him at the lake. That foolish, idiotic bet. Poor Lloyd -- I felt sorry for him. He'd have a cup of coffee with Mother and me. If a doorknob had come off he'd fix it. He'd carry the garbage cans to the curb. Someone dies, people try to be helpful. But he was by here so often that people started to talk. It was fairly obvious that he wanted something more from me than just a cup of coffee. I suggested that he didn't need to stop by here so often, but... then one afternoon I was at Woolworth's, having lunch at the counter. All of sudden Joan Abbott was standing there -- screaming and yelling at me to stop sleeping with her husband, with Lloyd. I was speechless. She was gone before I could find my tongue.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Christ... (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

Hollyoke, and Byrn Mawr. direction.raw_text: I'm sorry. I am so sorry. I was embarrassed. I didn't know where I was when I woke up. I felt like I was dying, so, I just... I was going to call you. Doug doesn't respond -- he turns the page of his book.

direction.raw_text: When I was cleaning you up, wiping the puke off your face, I suddenly realized how much I miss you -- how much I love you. How's that for stupid? Pam is stung by his flippancy, she begins to cry.

direction.raw_text: I love you.   But it's too late.

direction.raw_text: Everything's too screwed up. Doug kneels in front of her and anxiously tries to console her.

direction.raw_text: No, no, it's not too late. It's perfect timing. We're on our own now. No Jacey and Eleanor or Jacey and Alice. That's what stinks about being the youngest, we have to sweep up after everybody else. But now it's just us. It's our turn.

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How can you be in love with me?

direction.raw_text: 'Cause I've always have been. You... block-head. He kisses her, then he gazes at her and strokes her hair.

direction.raw_text: Hi.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi.

direction.raw_text: Doug leads Pam by the hand down the aisle from the lobby.

direction.raw_text: I want to show you something. He escorts her up a short flight of steps and positions her center stage near the footlights.

direction.raw_text: Doug!

direction.raw_text: Almost, almost... hold on. We hear Doug RUNNING somewhere backstage then a beautiful sunset slowly illuminates the stage -- creating the perfect mood for the modestly scaled stylized set that Doug has put into place: It is the roof of a weathered farmhouse with a dormer window and a tall brick chimney. Doug steps on stage, he's a bit winded from his quick- change routine.

direction.raw_text: Oh, Doug, it's beautiful.

direction.raw_text: The senior acting class does scenes from different plays, they invite everybody, it's a real big deal. So, there's this competition among all the theater design students to do the sets. And -- anyway -- I'm the one whose design got picked. (CONTINUED)

direction.raw_text: Umm... Romeo and Juliet. It's something different, I think that's why they picked it. Everybody else was doing castles and stuff. Rooftop Romeo and Juliet by Douglas L. Holt.

direction.raw_text: You're really good at this.

direction.raw_text: It's like building models when I was a kid. It's fun. It's... make-believe.

direction.raw_text: No! It's just too late. It's all messed up. I can't seem to make things all right. The more I try the worse everything gets. I'm sorry. Pam walks up the aisle and disappears through a door to the lobby.

direction.raw_text: Pam!   It's not too late! 144   OMITTED                                                     144 &       & 145
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - Rev. 3/20/96                     96. 146      OMITTED                                                        146 &        & 147                                                                     147 A148     INT. BRYN MAWR DORMITORY - LOBBY - LATER THAT NIGHT            A148 Pam enters the lobby. A female student CLERK (#1) displays a message as Pam passes by the front desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pam -- some guy named Doug keeps calling for you. Pam ignores the Clerk and the message and goes upstairs. 148      EXT. BRYN MAWR DORMITORY - DAY                                 148 Pamela approaches her dorm. She stops as she sees Doug waiting beside the entrance. She turns and walks away. A149     EXT. BRYN MAWR DORMITORY - NIGHT                               A149 Doug still waiting beside the entrance for some sign of Pam. He's tired, cold, and hungry. He grinds out his cigarette with his heel and walks away. B149   EXT. JACEY'S APT. (PHILADELPHIA STREET) - DAY (SUNDAY)       B149 149    INT. JACEY'S APARTMENT                                       149 Jacey sits in his favorite armchair reading the Sunday newspaper. Doug sits in the middle of the sofa. Jacey scrutinizes his brooding younger brother.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's wrong with you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing. A boiling water KETTLE starts to WHISTLE (O.S.) -- Jacey goes into the kitchen to tend to it. There is a soft KNOCK on the front door. Doug goes to answer it. He opens the door and finds Pamela standing there with her coat in her hand. He is pleasantly surprised; Pam is distant, slightly off-balance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - Rev. 3/20/96                     97. 149      CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How did you know I was here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You want another cup of... Jacey steps out of the kitchen and frowns when he sees Pam.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I told you not to come by on Sundays.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I forgot. The breath goes out of Doug as if he'd been struck in the stomach.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dammit, why didn't you call first?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Didn't have any nickels.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I didn't expect to see you again. You want to fuck? I mean, that's why you came over, right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then take off your clothes. Pamela drops her coat on the floor. She pulls her sweater off over her head. Doug's anguish is as great as Pamela's humiliation. He cannot bear any more if this -- he walks out the door. 150      EXT. JACEY'S APARTMENT (PHILADELPHIA) - SIDEWALK - DAY         150 Doug comes out of the apartment house and walks up the sidewalk. Tears begins to stream down his face. He begins to run and run as fast as he can. 151      INT. REED HALL (PHILADELPHIA) - LOBBY AND STAIRS -             151 THAT NIGHT Doug enters the dormitory and starts up the stairs. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - Rev. 3/20/96                   98. 151     CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) Doug... Doug turns and finds Jacey at the foot of the stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fuck you. Doug continues up the stairs -- Jacey pursues him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You didn't know what?!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How you felt about Pam.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fuck you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Apologize to her, you asshole!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I did. (slight beat) I ran into her a few weeks ago at a party. She was drinking and I... it was easy. She felt guilty about telling her father about Alice and me. Actually, I made her feel guilty, I made her feel like she had betrayed Alice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She didn't betray Alice! She was just trying to get rid of you so Alice wouldn't try to kill herself again. Jesus Christ, you shit- head, Alice couldn't marry you!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know.    I mean, I do now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then what the hell did Pam ever do to deserve your revenge?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 151     CONTINUED:   (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just your way of evening the score with Lloyd Abbott, right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Right. Doug spins and delivers a wild, roundhouse punch that lands brutally on the side of Jacey's face -- the impact knocks him down onto the steps. Jacey's eyebrow has split open, he is blinded by blood.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know   you! I don't know who the fuck   you are! You fuck everything.    You fuck everything up! Why did    you have to fuck Pam, too?! Doug walks away, leaving Jacey sitting on the steps, clutching a banister for support. He presses his palm to his eyebrow to squelch the flow of blood. 152     EXT. BRYN MAWR DORMITORY - DAY                                 152 Doug approaches Pam's dormitory. 153     INT. BRYN MAWR DORMITORY - LOBBY - DAY                         153 Doug steps up to the female student CLERK (#2) at the front desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pamela Abbott, please.     Tell her Doug is here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's not here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll wait.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But she left.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you mean?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She left... last night. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - Rev. 3/20/96                       100. 153     CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where did she go?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, did she go home?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No one seems to know. She just took some clothes and left.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, God... no... His pain is so clear that it spurs the Clerk's sympathy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, I'm not supposed to do this, but... well, I can give you her home address.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shit! Yeah, right... (slight beat) I mean... thanks. Thanks anyway. I know her home address. 154     EXT. ABBOTT HOME - STREET - DAY (DECEMBER, 1959)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Abbott house is decked with snow. Doug sits    behind the wheel of the Plymouth. He's parked down the    street. He smokes a cigarette and stares at the house --   the pavement outside the driver's window is littered   with butts. 155   EXT. SHOP (DOWNTOWN HALEY) - DAY                               155 Alice comes out on the street laden with packages and shopping bags. She's startled by Doug when he falls in beside her and follows her down the sidewalk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where's Pam?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is she with Eleanor? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - Rev. 3/20/96                     101. 155     CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In Chicago?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I couldn't find Eleanor's name in the Chicago phone book.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe it's unlisted.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, do you know Eleanor's address?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. I don't know her address, I don't know her phone number. You'd have to ask my father for it. All right? Alice turns and steps into another shop -- leaving Doug behind on the sidewalk. 156   INT. HOLT HOME - LIVING ROOM - NIGHT (CHRISTMAS, 1959)       156 PERRY COMO SINGS "The Little Drummer Boy" ON the TELEVISION. Doug rises from the sofa. 157     INT. HOLT HOME - KITCHEN - CONTINUOUS ACTION - NIGHT            157 Helen is peeling apples to make a pie.   Doug enters and studies her for a beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you okay?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm fine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You look... tired.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just a cold.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You sure? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - Rev. 3/20/96                    102. 157     CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I do wish Jacey had come home for Christmas. Maybe that's what's wrong with me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I guess that free-lance drafting job was too good for him to turn down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't think that's why he didn't come home. I wrote him a letter, you know. About Lloyd and me. Has he mentioned it to you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. Doug wants to avoid the topic of Jacey.    He opens the refrigerator.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When did you start drinking beer?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh... I bought those for you. I had them in the basement; I kept forgetting to bring them up. He does a bemused take on her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good heavens, I know you drink beer. Doug takes out two bottles of beer and opens them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here.   Have one with me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I bought those for you, honey.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's not good to drink alone, Mom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't be silly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on.   Sit down.   Have a beer. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 157     CONTINUED:   (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He pulls out a chair for her. She reluctantly comes over and sits down. Doug sits and proposes a toast.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merry Christmas.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merry Christmas. (takes a sip) It's beer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's drink 'em all. Helen laughs girlishly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charlie was always trying to get me to drink beer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why do you always call him Charlie?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That was his name.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why don't you ever say 'your father'?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sometimes I do, don't I? I don't know. When I think of him, I think of 'Charlie.'
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you ever... meet anybody else?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You mean another man?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, everyone always thinks things are more possible than they are. I mean, single men don't stay in Haley if they have any starch. The only eligible man around was Drew Carter, but he smells like his dog. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Her remark cracks Doug up -- Helen laughs, too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wish I'd remembered the beers sooner. It's nice to see you smiling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sorry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't be.   Everyone has sad times. Doug dissolves into tears. He lowers his head and shields his eyes with his hand. Helen leans over and strokes his hair. After a few moments, he rises and wipes away his tears with a dish towel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll tell you a secret. I did have a friend. A man in Chicago. I used to see him when I went up to Chicago to visit Bea during summer vacations.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'Used to see him' -- you don't see him anymore?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you like him?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He was a wonderful man. A little boring, but really, very wonderful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How long did this go on?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: About eight years or so, it was when you boys were still at home.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's a long time. Did you ever think about marrying him?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He proposed.   But, well, obviously, I said no. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 157      CONTINUED:   (4)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because I'm in love with... your father. With my memory of him. He was the one for me. Oh, I don't know... there's different kinds of love, darling. Some people you love no matter what. Other people you love if the situation is right. To me the best kind of love is the 'no matter what' kind. (slight beat) Well, I am a cheap drunk, aren't I? 158      EXT. COUNTRYSIDE - ROAD - DAYS LATER                            158 The bus cruises along the narrow ribbon of pavement. 159      INSIDE BUS - ANGLE ON DOUG                                      159 -- sitting by himself; there's not many passengers today. We hear the VOICES of rambunctious CHILDREN... 160      INT. HALEY ELEMENTARY SCHOOL - CLASSROOM - DAY                  160 (LATE SPRING, 1960) The second-grade students are in the midst of an art project where they make a design by gluing various sorts of dried beans to colored paper -- but the beans are being thrown about the room and other beans have been spilled on the floor. Helen wearily attempts to rein in the unruly children:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Too much noise, please. Let's finish up. Keep the glue on the paper. Sam, Lillian, Jack -- in your seats, please... Helen suddenly loses her energy and interest in policing the children. Their hijinks continue as she steps out of the classroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Helen steps over to a window and stares out -- lost in her own thoughts and oblivious to the NOISE from her classroom. 162      INT. UNIVERSITY OF PENNSYLVANIA - THEATER - DAY (LATE        162 SPRING, 1960) Doug is on a cat-walk in the fly loft high over the stage floor. He strains as he drops 20 pound slabs of pig-iron onto a counterweight carriage, then he releases the line and flies a canvas backdrop up into the loft. He locks off the line, wipes his brow, turns, and finds Jacey standing behind him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What-the-hell do you want?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doug sits in an almost empty terminal waiting to catch a red-eye flight to Chicago. A group of just arrived stewardesses pass by chatting with a captain and other flight officers. Eleanor Abbott does a take on Doug, steps away from her co-workers, and doubles back to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi, Doug! Doug almost doesn't recognize her. She is twenty years old now and very grown-up, very stylish in her stewardess uniform. She smiles at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How's your chin? (as he doesn't respond) Remember... the pencil?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.    I have a little scar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You going home? Back to Hole-in- the-Ground, Illinois.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My mother died. (CONTINUED) INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 3/20/96                   107. 163   CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (taken aback) Oh God. Oh no. Oh, Doug, I'm sorry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She had cancer. I just saw her Christmas. She was tired, but I thought she just had the flu or something. She didn't tell us. The hospital told Jacey when they called him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How is Jacey?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He had to stay to take his state board exams. He's coming back the day after tomorrow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's an architect?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If he passes his exams.   He will.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm so sorry, Doug.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know, I tried to find your phone number a couple of months ago.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's in my roommate's name, I've got to fix that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was wondering if you knew where Pam was?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.   I don't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She left school.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know.   My father called me. (MORE) (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 163     CONTINUED:   (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He was looking for her. I don't know where she is. I gotta run -- I'll miss my ride to the hotel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell Pam I love her. Eleanor looks at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell her... just tell her that. Eleanor doesn't reply.   She turns and walks away. 164     EXT. FUNERAL HOME (HALEY) - ALLEY - DAYS LATER                  164 The distance between Jacey and Doug is telling, as is the difference in their behavior. Doug leans against a wall with his hands in his pockets, his eyes cast down on his shoes. Jacey roams the alley unable to stand still for grief. He lights a fresh cigarette off the butt of another.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why?   Why didn't she tell us? The FUNERAL DIRECTOR appears in the back door:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gentlemen... 165     INT. FUNERAL HOME (HALEY) - DAY (MINUTES LATER)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Helen's closed casket is surrounded by floral tributes. Doug and Jacey enter from a door near the casket -- they pause in reaction to the crowded parlor, it overflows with mourners. Jacey explodes under his breath, so that only Doug can hear:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fucking hypocrites -- every one of 'em. Jacey turns and walks out through the door they came in. Doug walks over to his seat in the front row -- he hesitates when he sees Lloyd Abbott standing in the back of the parlor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 166      INT. HOLT HOME - DINING ROOM - NEXT DAY                          166 Doug sits at the table wrapping dishes in newspaper. Jacey comes in with a framed photograph of their grandmother.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you want this picture of Grandma?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can have it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You sure?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah. Jacey steps out of the dining room. 167      INT. HOLT HOME - HELEN'S BEDROOM - DAY (SHORT                    167 TIME LATER) Jacey is packing Helen's things.   Doug steps in the doorway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm starving. You want to go get something to eat? Jacey is caught a bit off-guard by Doug's invitation, then:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure. 168      INT. IRON SKILLET - NIGHT                                        168 Jacey and Doug are seated in a window booth.      They eat in silence, then:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't have to stick around.     I can handle things here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What about school?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hate Penn.   Always have.   You were right. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - Rev. 3/20/96                    110. 168     CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: About what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I should live my own life. Stop being your shadow. I'm not like you, Jacey -- I don't want to be like you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You going to stay here?   In Haley?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. I was thinking New York. If I'm going to really learn how to design sets, that's the place to do it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know you are. (slight beat) Did you have to get stitches?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hmmm?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your eyebrow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My eyebrow -- yeah, ten stitches.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sorry. Doug takes an envelope out of his coat pocket and puts it on the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Found this in one of the boxes in the basement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A letter of agreement between Lloyd Abbott and Dad. Dad sold him the file drawer patent -- not Mom. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 168     CONTINUED:   (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jacey opens the envelope and studies the yellowed document.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A car?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yup.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jesus Christ... he sold the patent for a used car?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Used cars were the only kind of cars around. The war was on -- everything was mobilized. They stopped making new cars, they were making tanks and bombers in Detroit. And even Midwest Steel wasn't making desks, they were making ammo boxes and mortar shells.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How did you get to be such an expert on World War Two?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .S. History -- high school. I should be an expert, I had to take the damn class twice. I guess Dad needed a car and he figured who- the-hell needed a full-suspension file drawer?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Desoto coupe convertible as is.'
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wonder whatever happened to it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He parked it at the bottom of the lake. 169     EXT. BUS DEPOT (DOWNTOWN HALEY) - NEXT DAY                    169 Doug follows Jacey to the door of the bus. Neither one of them knows how to say good-bye, after an awkward beat: (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 169     CONTINUED:                                                      169 JACEY (fighting back tears) Do me a favor. Don't stand here and wave good-bye... it makes me think of Mom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay.   See you. Doug turns and walks away.   Jacey climbs onto the bus. 170     EXT. ABBOTT HOME - STREET - DAY                                 170 Doug drives home from the bus depot in the old Plymouth. He slows as he sees... the party tent in the Abbotts' front yard (with its canvas sides rolled up). Susan's third birthday party is underway, dozens of well- dressed children and their parents are in attendance. Alice (who is very pregnant) and Peter Vanlaningham and Lloyd and Joan Abbott watch Susan riding her new pony, a gift from her grandparents. A new generation of Abbott parties has begun. 171     EXT. HOLT HOME - DRIVEWAY - DAY                                 171 A "For Sale" sign has been placed on the front yard. Doug pulls up the driveway in the Plymouth. He turns OFF the ENGINE but doesn't get out of the car. Then he STARTS the CAR again and backs out of the driveway. 172     INT. ABBOTT HOME - TENT - DAY (SHORT TIME LATER)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Despite it being a birthday party for a three-year-old, this is very much a grown-up affair. The band is playing, the adults are dancing, Joan Abbott is flitting from guest-to-guest, Alice is dutifully silent while Peter dominates the talk at their table, Lloyd is with his cronies. Doug enters the tent -- one-by-one the guests take notice of him as he works his way across the tent -- and all are very aware of his uninvited presence by the time he reaches Lloyd Abbott. Lloyd scrutinizes Doug, then:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you want?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want to talk to you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 173     INT. ABBOTT HOUSE - DEN - DAY                                   173 Doug follows Lloyd into the dark-paneled room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shut the door. Doug closes the door.   Lloyd lights a cigarette.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Smoke?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No thanks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sit down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't want to.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then don't. (slight beat) I'm sorry about your mother.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sorry about what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You didn't know your mother at all if you think someone like me would've ever stood a chance with someone like her. That just goes to show you how stupid this town is -- that they'd believe she slept with me. That'd make Charlie laugh. Your old man was my best friend. He used to call me 'Egg-head' -- hell, everybody did. And back then everybody knew that Egg-head Abbott didn't stand a snowball's chance in hell with Helen Riley. Of course, that was all before I became Lloyd Abbott
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Abbott. That was back when I still had chicken shit on my shoes and twelve cents in my pocket. Charlie Holt was the only one good enough for Helen. I used to spy on 'em -- yup, I did. (fixes a drink) Used to watch them sit on the front porch of her house -- your house -- and watch 'em talk. (MORE) (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - Rev. 3/20/96                   114. 173     CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And talk. I never knew what to say to a girl. Never could just talk. Could dance, could listen to the radio. But I couldn't talk... except with your mother, except with Helen. I talked more to her after your dad died than I'd ever talked to any woman before then -- or since then. Jesus, I talked. Just like this. Just like right now. Just pouring out. Helen would listen and whatever I said, she'd never make me feel bad or ignorant or guilty. I mean... for Christ's sake, she never blamed me for what happened at the lake, for letting Charlie drive out on that ice. She never did anything but try to make me hurt less and I... Lloyd is startled by Joan as she opens the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lloyd...?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get out of here!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's time for Susie's birthday cake.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goddammit, Joan, go way! Get the hell out of here! Leave me alone! He hurls his GLASS at her and it SHATTERS on the door jamb. Joan recoils in dumb-founded shock and backs out of the doorway. Lloyd fumes over and slams the door shut in her face. He leans against the door and catches his breath.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wanted sons -- isn't that funny? I wanted sons and I got three daughters. I wanted a woman I could talk to and I got a woman whose ears are stuffed full of money and Percodan. But I got the chicken shit off my shoes. (MORE) (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction
